However if #G_FILE_COPY_ALL_METADATA is specified in @flags, then all the metadata that is possible to copy is copied. This is useful when implementing move by copy + delete source.
function.return: %TRUE if the attributes were copied successfully, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_copy_finish
function.description: Finishes copying the file started with g_file_copy_async().
function.return: a %TRUE on success, %FALSE on error.

function.name: g_file_create
function.description:
Creates a new file and returns an output stream for writing to it. The file must not already exist.
By default files created are generally readable by everyone, but if you pass #G_FILE_CREATE_PRIVATE in @flags the file will be made readable only to the current user, to the level that is supported on the target filesystem.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If a file or directory with this name already exists the %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS error will be returned. Some file systems don't allow all file names, and may return an %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_FILENAME error, and if the name is to long %G_IO_ERROR_FILENAME_TOO_LONG will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
function.return: a #GFileOutputStream for the newly created file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_create_async
function.description:
Asynchronously creates a new file and returns an output stream for writing to it. The file must not already exist.
For more details, see g_file_create() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_create_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_create_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous file create operation started with g_file_create_async().
function.return: a #GFileOutputStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_create_readwrite
function.description:
Creates a new file and returns a stream for reading and writing to it. The file must not already exist.
By default files created are generally readable by everyone, but if you pass #G_FILE_CREATE_PRIVATE in @flags the file will be made readable only to the current user, to the level that is supported on the target filesystem.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If a file or directory with this name already exists, the %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS error will be returned. Some file systems don't allow all file names, and may return an %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_FILENAME error, and if the name is too long, %G_IO_ERROR_FILENAME_TOO_LONG will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
Note that in many non-local file cases read and write streams are not supported, so make sure you really need to do read and write streaming, rather than just opening for reading or writing.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GFileIOStream for the newly created file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_create_readwrite_async
function.description:
Asynchronously creates a new file and returns a stream for reading and writing to it. The file must not already exist.
For more details, see g_file_create_readwrite() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_create_readwrite_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_create_readwrite_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous file create operation started with g_file_create_readwrite_async().
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GFileIOStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_delete
function.description:
Deletes a file. If the @file is a directory, it will only be deleted if it is empty. This has the same semantics as g_unlink().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Virtual: delete_file
function.return: %TRUE if the file was deleted. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_delete_async
function.description:
Asynchronously delete a file. If the @file is a directory, it will only be deleted if it is empty. This has the same semantics as g_unlink().
Virtual: delete_file_async Since: 2.34

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_delete_finish
function.description:
Finishes deleting a file started with g_file_delete_async().
Virtual: delete_file_finish Since: 2.34

function.name: g_file_descriptor_based_get_fd
function.description:
Gets the underlying file descriptor.
Since: 2.24
function.return: The file descriptor

function.name: g_file_dup
function.description:
Duplicates a #GFile handle. This operation does not duplicate the actual file or directory represented by the #GFile; see g_file_copy() if attempting to copy a file.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a new #GFile that is a duplicate of the given #GFile.

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable
function.description:
Starts an asynchronous eject on a mountable. When this operation has completed, @callback will be called with @user_user data, and the operation can be finalized with g_file_eject_mountable_finish().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation() instead.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied, or %NULL

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous eject operation started by g_file_eject_mountable().
Deprecated: 2.22: Use g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation_finish() instead.
function.return: %TRUE if the @file was ejected successfully. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation
function.description:
Starts an asynchronous eject on a mountable. When this operation has completed, @callback will be called with @user_user data, and the operation can be finalized with g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation_finish().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation, or %NULL to avoid user interaction

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied, or %NULL

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous eject operation started by g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation().
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the @file was ejected successfully. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_enumerate_children
function.description:
Gets the requested information about the files in a directory. The result is a #GFileEnumerator object that will give out #GFileInfo objects for all the files in the directory.
The @attributes value is a string that specifies the file attributes that should be gathered. It is not an error if it's not possible to read a particular requested attribute from a file - it just won't be set. @attributes should be a comma-separated list of attributes or attribute wildcards. The wildcard "*" means all attributes, and a wildcard like "standard::*" means all attributes in the standard namespace. An example attribute query be "standard::*,owner::user". The standard attributes are available as defines, like #G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_NAME.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If the file does not exist, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error will be returned. If the file is not a directory, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_DIRECTORY error will be returned. Other errors are possible too.
function.return: A #GFileEnumerator if successful, %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_enumerate_children_async
function.description:
Asynchronously gets the requested information about the files in a directory. The result is a #GFileEnumerator object that will give out #GFileInfo objects for all the files in the directory.
For more details, see g_file_enumerate_children() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_enumerate_children_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_enumerate_children_finish
function.description: Finishes an async enumerate children operation. See g_file_enumerate_children_async().
function.return: a #GFileEnumerator or %NULL if an error occurred. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_enumerator_close
function.description:
Releases all resources used by this enumerator, making the enumerator return %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED on all calls.
This will be automatically called when the last reference is dropped, but you might want to call this function to make sure resources are released as early as possible.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: #TRUE on success or #FALSE on error.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_close_async
function.description:
Asynchronously closes the file enumerator.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned in g_file_enumerator_close_finish().

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_enumerator_close_finish
function.description:
Finishes closing a file enumerator, started from g_file_enumerator_close_async().
If the file enumerator was already closed when g_file_enumerator_close_async() was called, then this function will report %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED in @error, and return %FALSE. If the file enumerator had pending operation when the close operation was started, then this function will report %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING, and return %FALSE. If @cancellable was not %NULL, then the operation may have been cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be set, and %FALSE will be returned.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: %TRUE if the close operation has finished successfully.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_get_child

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFileInfo gotten from g_file_enumerator_next_file() or the async equivalents.

function.return: a #GFile for the #GFileInfo passed it.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_get_container
function.description:
Get the #GFile container which is being enumerated.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the #GFile which is being enumerated.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_has_pending
function.description: Checks if the file enumerator has pending operations.
function.return: %TRUE if the @enumerator has pending operations.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_is_closed
function.description: Checks if the file enumerator has been closed.
function.return: %TRUE if the @enumerator is closed.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_next_file
function.description:
Returns information for the next file in the enumerated object. Will block until the information is available. The #GFileInfo returned from this function will contain attributes that match the attribute string that was passed when the #GFileEnumerator was created.
On error, returns %NULL and sets @error to the error. If the enumerator is at the end, %NULL will be returned and @error will be unset.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: A #GFileInfo or %NULL on error or end of enumerator. Free the returned object with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_next_files_async
function.description:
Request information for a number of files from the enumerator asynchronously. When all i/o for the operation is finished the @callback will be called with the requested information.
The callback can be called with less than @num_files files in case of error or at the end of the enumerator. In case of a partial error the callback will be called with any succeeding items and no error, and on the next request the error will be reported. If a request is cancelled the callback will be called with %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED.
During an async request no other sync and async calls are allowed, and will result in %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING errors.
Any outstanding i/o request with higher priority (lower numerical value) will be executed before an outstanding request with lower priority. Default priority is %G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT.

parameter.name: num_files
parameter.parameter_description: the number of file info objects to request

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">io priority</link> of the request.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_enumerator_next_files_finish
function.description: Finishes the asynchronous operation started with g_file_enumerator_next_files_async().

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: a #GList of #GFileInfo<!---->s. You must free the list with g_list_free() and unref the infos with g_object_unref() when you're done with them.

function.name: g_file_enumerator_set_pending
function.description: Sets the file enumerator as having pending operations.

function.name: g_file_equal
function.description:
Checks equality of two given #GFiles.
Note that two #GFiles that differ can still refer to the same file on the filesystem due to various forms of filename aliasing.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: %TRUE if @file1 and @file2 are equal. %FALSE if either is not a #GFile.

function.name: g_file_find_enclosing_mount
function.description:
Gets a #GMount for the #GFile.
If the #GFileIface for @file does not have a mount (e.g. possibly a remote share), @error will be set to %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND and %NULL will be returned.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
function.return: a #GMount where the @file is located or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_find_enclosing_mount_async
function.description:
Asynchronously gets the mount for the file.
For more details, see g_file_find_enclosing_mount() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_find_enclosing_mount_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_find_enclosing_mount_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous find mount request. See g_file_find_enclosing_mount_async().
function.return: #GMount for given @file or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_get_basename
function.description:
Gets the base name (the last component of the path) for a given #GFile.
If called for the top level of a system (such as the filesystem root or a uri like sftp://host/) it will return a single directory separator (and on Windows, possibly a drive letter).
The base name is a byte string (not UTF-8). It has no defined encoding or rules other than it may not contain zero bytes. If you want to use filenames in a user interface you should use the display name that you can get by requesting the %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_DISPLAY_NAME attribute with g_file_query_info().
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: string containing the #GFile's base name, or %NULL if given #GFile is invalid. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_get_child
function.description:
Gets a child of @file with basename equal to @name.
Note that the file with that specific name might not exist, but you can still have a #GFile that points to it. You can use this for instance to create that file.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a #GFile to a child specified by @name. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_get_child_for_display_name
function.description:
Gets the child of @file for a given @display_name (i.e. a UTF-8 version of the name). If this function fails, it returns %NULL and @error will be set. This is very useful when constructing a #GFile for a new file and the user entered the filename in the user interface, for instance when you select a directory and type a filename in the file selector.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a #GFile to the specified child, or %NULL if the display name couldn't be converted. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_get_parent
function.description:
Gets the parent directory for the @file. If the @file represents the root directory of the file system, then %NULL will be returned.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a #GFile structure to the parent of the given #GFile or %NULL if there is no parent. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_get_parse_name
function.description:
Gets the parse name of the @file. A parse name is a UTF-8 string that describes the file such that one can get the #GFile back using g_file_parse_name().
This is generally used to show the #GFile as a nice full-pathname kind of string in a user interface, like in a location entry.
For local files with names that can safely be converted to UTF-8 the pathname is used, otherwise the IRI is used (a form of URI that allows UTF-8 characters unescaped).
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a string containing the #GFile's parse name. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_get_path
function.description:
Gets the local pathname for #GFile, if one exists.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: string containing the #GFile's path, or %NULL if no such path exists. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_get_relative_path
function.description:
Gets the path for @descendant relative to @parent.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: string with the relative path from @descendant to @parent, or %NULL if @descendant doesn't have @parent as prefix. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_get_uri
function.description:
Gets the URI for the @file.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a string containing the #GFile's URI. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_get_uri_scheme
function.description:
Gets the URI scheme for a #GFile. RFC 3986 decodes the scheme as: <programlisting> URI = scheme ":" hier-part [ "?" query ] [ "#" fragment ] </programlisting> Common schemes include "file", "http", "ftp", etc.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a string containing the URI scheme for the given #GFile. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_file_has_parent
function.description:
Checks if @file has a parent, and optionally, if it is @parent.
If @parent is %NULL then this function returns %TRUE if @file has any parent at all. If @parent is non-%NULL then %TRUE is only returned if @file is a child of @parent.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: the parent to check for, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if @file is a child of @parent (or any parent in the case that @parent is %NULL).

function.name: g_file_has_prefix
function.description:
Checks whether @file has the prefix specified by @prefix.
In other words, if the names of initial elements of @file's pathname match @prefix. Only full pathname elements are matched, so a path like /foo is not considered a prefix of /foobar, only of /foo/bar.
This call does no I/O, as it works purely on names. As such it can sometimes return %FALSE even if @file is inside a @prefix (from a filesystem point of view), because the prefix of @file is an alias of @prefix.
Virtual: prefix_matches
function.return: %TRUE if the @files's parent, grandparent, etc is @prefix, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_has_uri_scheme
function.description:
Checks to see if a #GFile has a given URI scheme.
This call does no blocking I/O.

parameter.name: uri_scheme
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a URI scheme

function.return: %TRUE if #GFile's backend supports the given URI scheme, %FALSE if URI scheme is %NULL, not supported, or #GFile is invalid.

function.name: g_file_hash
function.description:
Creates a hash value for a #GFile.
This call does no blocking I/O.
Virtual: hash
function.return: 0 if @file is not a valid #GFile, otherwise an integer that can be used as hash value for the #GFile. This function is intended for easily hashing a #GFile to add to a #GHashTable or similar data structure.

function.name: g_file_icon_get_file
function.description: Gets the #GFile associated with the given @icon.
function.return: a #GFile, or %NULL.

function.name: g_file_icon_new
function.description: Creates a new icon for a file.
function.return: a #GIcon for the given @file, or %NULL on error.

function.name: g_file_info_clear_status
function.description: Clears the status information from @info.

function.name: g_file_info_copy_into
function.description: Copies all of the <link linkend="gio-GFileAttribute">GFileAttribute</link>s from @src_info to @dest_info.

function.name: g_file_info_dup
function.description: Duplicates a file info structure.
function.return: a duplicate #GFileInfo of @other.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_as_string
function.description: Gets the value of a attribute, formated as a string. This escapes things as needed to make the string valid utf8.
function.return: a UTF-8 string associated with the given @attribute. When you're done with the string it must be freed with g_free().

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_boolean
function.description: Gets the value of a boolean attribute. If the attribute does not contain a boolean value, %FALSE will be returned.
function.return: the boolean value contained within the attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_byte_string
function.description: Gets the value of a byte string attribute. If the attribute does not contain a byte string, %NULL will be returned.
function.return: the contents of the @attribute value as a byte string, or %NULL otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_data
function.description: Gets the attribute type, value and status for an attribute key.

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the attribute type, or %NULL

parameter.name: value_pp
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the attribute value, or %NULL

parameter.name: status
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the attribute status, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if @info has an attribute named @attribute, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_int32
function.description: Gets a signed 32-bit integer contained within the attribute. If the attribute does not contain a signed 32-bit integer, or is invalid, 0 will be returned.
function.return: a signed 32-bit integer from the attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_int64
function.description: Gets a signed 64-bit integer contained within the attribute. If the attribute does not contain an signed 64-bit integer, or is invalid, 0 will be returned.
function.return: a signed 64-bit integer from the attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_object
function.description: Gets the value of a #GObject attribute. If the attribute does not contain a #GObject, %NULL will be returned.
function.return: a #GObject associated with the given @attribute, or %NULL otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_status
function.description: Gets the attribute status for an attribute key.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeStatus for the given @attribute, or %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STATUS_UNSET if the key is invalid.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_string
function.description: Gets the value of a string attribute. If the attribute does not contain a string, %NULL will be returned.
function.return: the contents of the @attribute value as a UTF-8 string, or %NULL otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_stringv
function.description:
Gets the value of a stringv attribute. If the attribute does not contain a stringv, %NULL will be returned.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the contents of the @attribute value as a stringv, or %NULL otherwise. Do not free. These returned strings are UTF-8.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_type
function.description: Gets the attribute type for an attribute key.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeType for the given @attribute, or %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TYPE_INVALID if the key is not set.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_uint32
function.description: Gets an unsigned 32-bit integer contained within the attribute. If the attribute does not contain an unsigned 32-bit integer, or is invalid, 0 will be returned.
function.return: an unsigned 32-bit integer from the attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_attribute_uint64
function.description: Gets a unsigned 64-bit integer contained within the attribute. If the attribute does not contain an unsigned 64-bit integer, or is invalid, 0 will be returned.
function.return: a unsigned 64-bit integer from the attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_content_type
function.description: Gets the file's content type.
function.return: a string containing the file's content type.

function.name: g_file_info_get_deletion_date
function.description:
Returns the #GDateTime representing the deletion date of the file, as available in G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TRASH_DELETION_DATE. If the G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TRASH_DELETION_DATE attribute is unset, %NULL is returned.
Since: 2.36
function.return: a #GDateTime, or %NULL.

function.name: g_file_info_get_display_name
function.description: Gets a display name for a file.
function.return: a string containing the display name.

function.name: g_file_info_get_edit_name
function.description: Gets the edit name for a file.
function.return: a string containing the edit name.

function.name: g_file_info_get_etag
function.description: Gets the <link linkend="gfile-etag">entity tag</link> for a given #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ETAG_VALUE.
function.return: a string containing the value of the "etag:value" attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_file_type
function.description: Gets a file's type (whether it is a regular file, symlink, etc). This is different from the file's content type, see g_file_info_get_content_type().
function.return: a #GFileType for the given file.

function.name: g_file_info_get_icon
function.description: Gets the icon for a file.
function.return: #GIcon for the given @info.

function.name: g_file_info_get_is_backup
function.description: Checks if a file is a backup file.
function.return: %TRUE if file is a backup file, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_get_is_hidden
function.description: Checks if a file is hidden.
function.return: %TRUE if the file is a hidden file, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_get_is_symlink
function.description: Checks if a file is a symlink.
function.return: %TRUE if the given @info is a symlink.

function.name: g_file_info_get_modification_time
function.description: Gets the modification time of the current @info and sets it in @result.

function.name: g_file_info_get_name
function.description: Gets the name for a file.
function.return: a string containing the file name.

function.name: g_file_info_get_size
function.description: Gets the file's size.
function.return: a #goffset containing the file's size.

function.name: g_file_info_get_sort_order
function.description: Gets the value of the sort_order attribute from the #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_SORT_ORDER.
function.return: a #gint32 containing the value of the "standard::sort_order" attribute.

function.name: g_file_info_get_symbolic_icon
function.description:
Gets the symbolic icon for a file.
Since: 2.34
function.return: #GIcon for the given @info.

function.name: g_file_info_get_symlink_target
function.description: Gets the symlink target for a given #GFileInfo.
function.return: a string containing the symlink target.

function.name: g_file_info_has_attribute
function.description: Checks if a file info structure has an attribute named @attribute.
function.return: %TRUE if @Ginfo has an attribute named @attribute, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_has_namespace
function.description:
Checks if a file info structure has an attribute in the specified @name_space.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if @Ginfo has an attribute in @name_space, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_info_list_attributes
function.description: Lists the file info structure's attributes.
function.return: a null-terminated array of strings of all of the possible attribute types for the given @name_space, or %NULL on error.

function.name: g_file_info_new
function.description: Creates a new file info structure.
function.return: a #GFileInfo.

function.name: g_file_info_remove_attribute
function.description: Removes all cases of @attribute from @info if it exists.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given value, if possible. To unset the attribute, use %G_ATTRIBUTE_TYPE_INVALID for @type.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_boolean
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_byte_string
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_int32
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_int64
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

parameter.name: attr_value
parameter.parameter_description: int64 value to set attribute to.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_mask
function.description: Sets @mask on @info to match specific attribute types.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_object
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_status
function.description:
Sets the attribute status for an attribute key. This is only needed by external code that implement g_file_set_attributes_from_info() or similar functions.
The attribute must exist in @info for this to work. Otherwise %FALSE is returned and @info is unchanged.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the status was changed, %FALSE if the key was not set.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_string
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_stringv
function.description:
Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.
Sinze: 2.22

parameter.name: attr_value
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL terminated array of UTF-8 strings.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_uint32
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_attribute_uint64
function.description: Sets the @attribute to contain the given @attr_value, if possible.

function.name: g_file_info_set_content_type
function.description: Sets the content type attribute for a given #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_CONTENT_TYPE.

function.name: g_file_info_set_display_name
function.description: Sets the display name for the current #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_DISPLAY_NAME.

parameter.name: display_name
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a display name.

function.name: g_file_info_set_edit_name
function.description: Sets the edit name for the current file. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_EDIT_NAME.

parameter.name: edit_name
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing an edit name.

function.name: g_file_info_set_file_type
function.description: Sets the file type in a #GFileInfo to @type. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_TYPE.

function.name: g_file_info_set_icon
function.description: Sets the icon for a given #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_ICON.

function.name: g_file_info_set_is_hidden
function.description: Sets the "is_hidden" attribute in a #GFileInfo according to @is_symlink. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_IS_HIDDEN.

function.name: g_file_info_set_is_symlink
function.description: Sets the "is_symlink" attribute in a #GFileInfo according to @is_symlink. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_IS_SYMLINK.

function.name: g_file_info_set_modification_time
function.description: Sets the %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TIME_MODIFIED attribute in the file info to the given time value.

function.name: g_file_info_set_name
function.description: Sets the name attribute for the current #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_NAME.

function.name: g_file_info_set_size
function.description: Sets the %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_SIZE attribute in the file info to the given size.

function.name: g_file_info_set_sort_order
function.description: Sets the sort order attribute in the file info structure. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_SORT_ORDER.

function.name: g_file_info_set_symbolic_icon
function.description:
Sets the symbolic icon for a given #GFileInfo. See %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_SYMBOLIC_ICON.
Since: 2.34

function.name: g_file_info_set_symlink_target
function.description: Sets the %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_SYMLINK_TARGET attribute in the file info to the given symlink target.

parameter.name: symlink_target
parameter.parameter_description: a static string containing a path to a symlink target.

function.name: g_file_info_unset_attribute_mask
function.description: Unsets a mask set by g_file_info_set_attribute_mask(), if one is set.

function.name: g_file_input_stream_query_info
function.description: Queries a file input stream the given @attributes. This function blocks while querying the stream. For the asynchronous (non-blocking) version of this function, see g_file_input_stream_query_info_async(). While the stream is blocked, the stream will set the pending flag internally, and any other operations on the stream will fail with %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: a #GFileInfo, or %NULL on error.

function.name: g_file_input_stream_query_info_async
function.description:
Queries the stream information asynchronously. When the operation is finished @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_input_stream_query_info_finish() to get the result of the operation.
For the synchronous version of this function, see g_file_input_stream_query_info().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be set

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_input_stream_query_info_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous info query operation.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: #GFileInfo.

function.name: g_file_io_stream_get_etag
function.description:
Gets the entity tag for the file when it has been written. This must be called after the stream has been written and closed, as the etag can change while writing.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the entity tag for the stream.

function.name: g_file_io_stream_query_info
function.description:
Queries a file io stream for the given @attributes. This function blocks while querying the stream. For the asynchronous version of this function, see g_file_io_stream_query_info_async(). While the stream is blocked, the stream will set the pending flag internally, and any other operations on the stream will fail with %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING.
Can fail if the stream was already closed (with @error being set to %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED), the stream has pending operations (with @error being set to %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING), or if querying info is not supported for the stream's interface (with @error being set to %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED). I all cases of failure, %NULL will be returned.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be set, and %NULL will be returned.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GFileInfo for the @stream, or %NULL on error.

function.name: g_file_io_stream_query_info_async
function.description:
Asynchronously queries the @stream for a #GFileInfo. When completed, @callback will be called with a #GAsyncResult which can be used to finish the operation with g_file_io_stream_query_info_finish().
For the synchronous version of this function, see g_file_io_stream_query_info().
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="gio-GIOScheduler">I/O priority</link> of the request.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_io_stream_query_info_finish
function.description:
Finalizes the asynchronous query started by g_file_io_stream_query_info_async().
Since: 2.22
function.return: A #GFileInfo for the finished query.

function.name: g_file_is_native
function.description:
Checks to see if a file is native to the platform.
A native file s one expressed in the platform-native filename format, e.g. "C:\Windows" or "/usr/bin/". This does not mean the file is local, as it might be on a locally mounted remote filesystem.
On some systems non-native files may be available using the native filesystem via a userspace filesystem (FUSE), in these cases this call will return %FALSE, but g_file_get_path() will still return a native path.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: %TRUE if @file is native

function.name: g_file_load_contents
function.description:
Loads the content of the file into memory. The data is always zero-terminated, but this is not included in the resultant @length. The returned @content should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the contents of the file

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the length of the contents of the file, or %NULL if the length is not needed

parameter.name: etag_out
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the current entity tag for the file, or %NULL if the entity tag is not needed

function.return: %TRUE if the @file's contents were successfully loaded. %FALSE if there were errors.

function.name: g_file_load_contents_async
function.description:
Starts an asynchronous load of the @file's contents.
For more details, see g_file_load_contents() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the load operation has completed, @callback will be called with @user data. To finish the operation, call g_file_load_contents_finish() with the #GAsyncResult returned by the @callback.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_load_contents_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous load of the @file's contents. The contents are placed in @contents, and @length is set to the size of the @contents string. The @content should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed. If @etag_out is present, it will be set to the new entity tag for the @file.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the contents of the file

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the length of the contents of the file, or %NULL if the length is not needed

parameter.name: etag_out
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the current entity tag for the file, or %NULL if the entity tag is not needed

function.return: %TRUE if the load was successful. If %FALSE and @error is present, it will be set appropriately.

function.name: g_file_load_partial_contents_async
function.description:
Reads the partial contents of a file. A #GFileReadMoreCallback should be used to stop reading from the file when appropriate, else this function will behave exactly as g_file_load_contents_async(). This operation can be finished by g_file_load_partial_contents_finish().
Users of this function should be aware that @user_data is passed to both the @read_more_callback and the @callback.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.

parameter.name: read_more_callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFileReadMoreCallback to receive partial data and to specify whether further data should be read

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback functions

function.name: g_file_load_partial_contents_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous partial load operation that was started with g_file_load_partial_contents_async(). The data is always zero-terminated, but this is not included in the resultant @length. The returned @content should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the contents of the file

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the length of the contents of the file, or %NULL if the length is not needed

parameter.name: etag_out
parameter.parameter_description: a location to place the current entity tag for the file, or %NULL if the entity tag is not needed

function.return: %TRUE if the load was successful. If %FALSE and @error is present, it will be set appropriately.

function.name: g_file_make_directory
function.description:
Creates a directory. Note that this will only create a child directory of the immediate parent directory of the path or URI given by the #GFile. To recursively create directories, see g_file_make_directory_with_parents(). This function will fail if the parent directory does not exist, setting @error to %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND. If the file system doesn't support creating directories, this function will fail, setting @error to %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED.
For a local #GFile the newly created directory will have the default (current) ownership and permissions of the current process.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
function.return: %TRUE on successful creation, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_make_directory_with_parents
function.description:
Creates a directory and any parent directories that may not exist similar to 'mkdir -p'. If the file system does not support creating directories, this function will fail, setting @error to %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED. If the directory itself already exists, this function will fail setting @error to %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS, unlike the similar g_mkdir_with_parents().
For a local #GFile the newly created directories will have the default (current) ownership and permissions of the current process.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Since: 2.18
function.return: %TRUE if all directories have been successfully created, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_make_symbolic_link
function.description:
Creates a symbolic link named @file which contains the string @symlink_value.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFile with the name of the symlink to create

parameter.name: symlink_value
parameter.parameter_description: a string with the path for the target of the new symlink

function.return: %TRUE on the creation of a new symlink, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_monitor
function.description:
Obtains a file or directory monitor for the given file, depending on the type of the file.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a #GFileMonitor for the given @file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_monitor_cancel
function.description: Cancels a file monitor.
function.return: %TRUE if monitor was cancelled.

function.name: g_file_monitor_directory
function.description:
Obtains a directory monitor for the given file. This may fail if directory monitoring is not supported.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
It does not make sense for @flags to contain %G_FILE_MONITOR_WATCH_HARD_LINKS, since hard links can not be made to directories. It is not possible to monitor all the files in a directory for changes made via hard links; if you want to do this then you must register individual watches with g_file_monitor().
Virtual: monitor_dir
function.return: a #GFileMonitor for the given @file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_monitor_emit_event
function.description:
Emits the #GFileMonitor::changed signal if a change has taken place. Should be called from file monitor implementations only.
The signal will be emitted from an idle handler (in the <link linkend="g-main-context-push-thread-default">thread-default main context</link>).

function.name: g_file_monitor_file
function.description:
Obtains a file monitor for the given file. If no file notification mechanism exists, then regular polling of the file is used.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If @flags contains %G_FILE_MONITOR_WATCH_HARD_LINKS then the monitor will also attempt to report changes made to the file via another filename (ie, a hard link). Without this flag, you can only rely on changes made through the filename contained in @file to be reported. Using this flag may result in an increase in resource usage, and may not have any effect depending on the #GFileMonitor backend and/or filesystem type.
function.return: a #GFileMonitor for the given @file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_monitor_is_cancelled
function.description: Returns whether the monitor is canceled.
function.return: %TRUE if monitor is canceled. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_monitor_set_rate_limit
function.description: Sets the rate limit to which the @monitor will report consecutive change events to the same file.

parameter.name: limit_msecs
parameter.parameter_description: a non-negative integer with the limit in milliseconds to poll for changes

function.name: g_file_mount_enclosing_volume
function.description:
Starts a @mount_operation, mounting the volume that contains the file @location.
When this operation has completed, @callback will be called with @user_user data, and the operation can be finalized with g_file_mount_enclosing_volume_finish().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied, or %NULL

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_mount_enclosing_volume_finish
function.description: Finishes a mount operation started by g_file_mount_enclosing_volume().
function.return: %TRUE if successful. If an error has occurred, this function will return %FALSE and set @error appropriately if present.

function.name: g_file_mount_mountable
function.description:
Mounts a file of type G_FILE_TYPE_MOUNTABLE. Using @mount_operation, you can request callbacks when, for instance, passwords are needed during authentication.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_mount_mountable_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation, or %NULL to avoid user interaction

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied, or %NULL

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_mount_mountable_finish
function.description:
Finishes a mount operation. See g_file_mount_mountable() for details.
Finish an asynchronous mount operation that was started with g_file_mount_mountable().
function.return: a #GFile or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_move
function.description:
Tries to move the file or directory @source to the location specified by @destination. If native move operations are supported then this is used, otherwise a copy + delete fallback is used. The native implementation may support moving directories (for instance on moves inside the same filesystem), but the fallback code does not.
If the flag #G_FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE is specified an already existing @destination file is overwritten.
If the flag #G_FILE_COPY_NOFOLLOW_SYMLINKS is specified then symlinks will be copied as symlinks, otherwise the target of the @source symlink will be copied.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If @progress_callback is not %NULL, then the operation can be monitored by setting this to a #GFileProgressCallback function. @progress_callback_data will be passed to this function. It is guaranteed that this callback will be called after all data has been transferred with the total number of bytes copied during the operation.
If the @source file does not exist, then the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error is returned, independent on the status of the @destination.
If #G_FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE is not specified and the target exists, then the error %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS is returned.
If trying to overwrite a file over a directory, the %G_IO_ERROR_IS_DIRECTORY error is returned. If trying to overwrite a directory with a directory the %G_IO_ERROR_WOULD_MERGE error is returned.
If the source is a directory and the target does not exist, or #G_FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE is specified and the target is a file, then the %G_IO_ERROR_WOULD_RECURSE error may be returned (if the native move operation isn't available).

parameter.name: progress_callback_data
parameter.parameter_description: gpointer to user data for the callback function

function.return: %TRUE on successful move, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_new_for_commandline_arg
function.description: Creates a #GFile with the given argument from the command line. The value of @arg can be either a URI, an absolute path or a relative path resolved relative to the current working directory. This operation never fails, but the returned object might not support any I/O operation if @arg points to a malformed path.
function.return: a new #GFile. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_new_for_commandline_arg_and_cwd
function.description:
Creates a #GFile with the given argument from the command line.
This function is similar to g_file_new_for_commandline_arg() except that it allows for passing the current working directory as an argument instead of using the current working directory of the process.
This is useful if the commandline argument was given in a context other than the invocation of the current process.
See also g_application_command_line_create_file_for_arg().
Since: 2.36

parameter.name: cwd
parameter.parameter_description: the current working directory of the commandline

function.return: a new #GFile

function.name: g_file_new_for_path
function.description: Constructs a #GFile for a given path. This operation never fails, but the returned object might not support any I/O operation if @path is malformed.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a relative or absolute path. The string must be encoded in the glib filename encoding.

function.return: a new #GFile for the given @path. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_new_for_uri
function.description: Constructs a #GFile for a given URI. This operation never fails, but the returned object might not support any I/O operation if @uri is malformed or if the uri type is not supported.

parameter.name: uri
parameter.parameter_description: a UTF-8 string containing a URI

function.return: a new #GFile for the given @uri. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_new_tmp
function.description:
Opens a file in the preferred directory for temporary files (as returned by g_get_tmp_dir()) and returns a #GFile and #GFileIOStream pointing to it.
@tmpl should be a string in the GLib file name encoding containing a sequence of six 'X' characters, and containing no directory components. If it is %NULL, a default template is used.
Unlike the other #GFile constructors, this will return %NULL if a temporary file could not be created.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: tmpl
parameter.parameter_description: Template for the file name, as in g_file_open_tmp(), or %NULL for a default template

parameter.name: iostream
parameter.parameter_description: on return, a #GFileIOStream for the created file

function.return: a new #GFile. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_open_readwrite
function.description:
Opens an existing file for reading and writing. The result is a #GFileIOStream that can be used to read and write the contents of the file.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If the file does not exist, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error will be returned. If the file is a directory, the %G_IO_ERROR_IS_DIRECTORY error will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on. Note that in many non-local file cases read and write streams are not supported, so make sure you really need to do read and write streaming, rather than just opening for reading or writing.
Since: 2.22
function.return: #GFileIOStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_open_readwrite_async
function.description:
Asynchronously opens @file for reading and writing.
For more details, see g_file_open_readwrite() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_open_readwrite_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_open_readwrite_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous file read operation started with g_file_open_readwrite_async().
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GFileIOStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_output_stream_get_etag
function.description: Gets the entity tag for the file when it has been written. This must be called after the stream has been written and closed, as the etag can change while writing.
function.return: the entity tag for the stream.

function.name: g_file_output_stream_query_info
function.description:
Queries a file output stream for the given @attributes. This function blocks while querying the stream. For the asynchronous version of this function, see g_file_output_stream_query_info_async(). While the stream is blocked, the stream will set the pending flag internally, and any other operations on the stream will fail with %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING.
Can fail if the stream was already closed (with @error being set to %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED), the stream has pending operations (with @error being set to %G_IO_ERROR_PENDING), or if querying info is not supported for the stream's interface (with @error being set to %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED). In all cases of failure, %NULL will be returned.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be set, and %NULL will be returned.
function.return: a #GFileInfo for the @stream, or %NULL on error.

function.name: g_file_output_stream_query_info_async
function.description:
Asynchronously queries the @stream for a #GFileInfo. When completed, @callback will be called with a #GAsyncResult which can be used to finish the operation with g_file_output_stream_query_info_finish().
For the synchronous version of this function, see g_file_output_stream_query_info().

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="gio-GIOScheduler">I/O priority</link> of the request.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_output_stream_query_info_finish
function.description: Finalizes the asynchronous query started by g_file_output_stream_query_info_async().
function.return: A #GFileInfo for the finished query.

function.name: g_file_parse_name
function.description: Constructs a #GFile with the given @parse_name (i.e. something given by g_file_get_parse_name()). This operation never fails, but the returned object might not support any I/O operation if the @parse_name cannot be parsed.

parameter.name: parse_name
parameter.parameter_description: a file name or path to be parsed

function.return: a new #GFile.

function.name: g_file_poll_mountable
function.description:
Polls a file of type #G_FILE_TYPE_MOUNTABLE.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_mount_mountable_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied, or %NULL

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_poll_mountable_finish
function.description:
Finishes a poll operation. See g_file_poll_mountable() for details.
Finish an asynchronous poll operation that was polled with g_file_poll_mountable().
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the operation finished successfully. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_query_default_handler
function.description:
Returns the #GAppInfo that is registered as the default application to handle the file specified by @file.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
function.return: a #GAppInfo if the handle was found, %NULL if there were errors. When you are done with it, release it with g_object_unref()

function.name: g_file_query_exists
function.description:
Utility function to check if a particular file exists. This is implemented using g_file_query_info() and as such does blocking I/O.
Note that in many cases it is racy to first check for file existence and then execute something based on the outcome of that, because the file might have been created or removed in between the operations. The general approach to handling that is to not check, but just do the operation and handle the errors as they come.
As an example of race-free checking, take the case of reading a file, and if it doesn't exist, creating it. There are two racy versions: read it, and on error create it; and: check if it exists, if not create it. These can both result in two processes creating the file (with perhaps a partially written file as the result). The correct approach is to always try to create the file with g_file_create() which will either atomically create the file or fail with a %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS error.
However, in many cases an existence check is useful in a user interface, for instance to make a menu item sensitive/insensitive, so that you don't have to fool users that something is possible and then just show an error dialog. If you do this, you should make sure to also handle the errors that can happen due to races when you execute the operation.
function.return: %TRUE if the file exists (and can be detected without error), %FALSE otherwise (or if cancelled).

function.name: g_file_query_file_type
function.description:
Utility function to inspect the #GFileType of a file. This is implemented using g_file_query_info() and as such does blocking I/O.
The primary use case of this method is to check if a file is a regular file, directory, or symlink.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: a set of #GFileQueryInfoFlags passed to g_file_query_info()

function.return: The #GFileType of the file and #G_FILE_TYPE_UNKNOWN if the file does not exist

function.name: g_file_query_filesystem_info
function.description:
Similar to g_file_query_info(), but obtains information about the filesystem the @file is on, rather than the file itself. For instance the amount of space available and the type of the filesystem.
The @attributes value is a string that specifies the attributes that should be gathered. It is not an error if it's not possible to read a particular requested attribute from a file - it just won't be set. @attributes should be a comma-separated list of attributes or attribute wildcards. The wildcard "*" means all attributes, and a wildcard like "filesystem::*" means all attributes in the filesystem namespace. The standard namespace for filesystem attributes is "filesystem". Common attributes of interest are #G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_FILESYSTEM_SIZE (the total size of the filesystem in bytes), #G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_FILESYSTEM_FREE (number of bytes available), and #G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_FILESYSTEM_TYPE (type of the filesystem).
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If the file does not exist, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
function.return: a #GFileInfo or %NULL if there was an error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_query_filesystem_info_async
function.description:
Asynchronously gets the requested information about the filesystem that the specified @file is on. The result is a #GFileInfo object that contains key-value attributes (such as type or size for the file).
For more details, see g_file_query_filesystem_info() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_query_info_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_query_filesystem_info_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous filesystem info query. See g_file_query_filesystem_info_async().
function.return: #GFileInfo for given @file or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_query_info
function.description:
Gets the requested information about specified @file. The result is a #GFileInfo object that contains key-value attributes (such as the type or size of the file).
The @attributes value is a string that specifies the file attributes that should be gathered. It is not an error if it's not possible to read a particular requested attribute from a file - it just won't be set. @attributes should be a comma-separated list of attributes or attribute wildcards. The wildcard "*" means all attributes, and a wildcard like "standard::*" means all attributes in the standard namespace. An example attribute query be "standard::*,owner::user". The standard attributes are available as defines, like #G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_NAME.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
For symlinks, normally the information about the target of the symlink is returned, rather than information about the symlink itself. However if you pass #G_FILE_QUERY_INFO_NOFOLLOW_SYMLINKS in @flags the information about the symlink itself will be returned. Also, for symlinks that point to non-existing files the information about the symlink itself will be returned.
If the file does not exist, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
function.return: a #GFileInfo for the given @file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_query_info_async
function.description:
Asynchronously gets the requested information about specified @file. The result is a #GFileInfo object that contains key-value attributes (such as type or size for the file).
For more details, see g_file_query_info() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_query_info_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_query_info_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous file info query. See g_file_query_info_async().
function.return: #GFileInfo for given @file or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_query_settable_attributes
function.description: Obtain the list of settable attributes for the file.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeInfoList describing the settable attributes. When you are done with it, release it with g_file_attribute_info_list_unref()

function.name: g_file_query_writable_namespaces
function.description:
Obtain the list of attribute namespaces where new attributes can be created by a user. An example of this is extended attributes (in the "xattr" namespace).
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeInfoList describing the writable namespaces. When you are done with it, release it with g_file_attribute_info_list_unref()

function.name: g_file_read
function.description:
Opens a file for reading. The result is a #GFileInputStream that can be used to read the contents of the file.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If the file does not exist, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error will be returned. If the file is a directory, the %G_IO_ERROR_IS_DIRECTORY error will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
Virtual: read_fn
function.return: #GFileInputStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_read_async
function.description:
Asynchronously opens @file for reading.
For more details, see g_file_read() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_read_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_read_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous file read operation started with g_file_read_async().
function.return: a #GFileInputStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_replace
function.description:
Returns an output stream for overwriting the file, possibly creating a backup copy of the file first. If the file doesn't exist, it will be created.
This will try to replace the file in the safest way possible so that any errors during the writing will not affect an already existing copy of the file. For instance, for local files it may write to a temporary file and then atomically rename over the destination when the stream is closed.
By default files created are generally readable by everyone, but if you pass #G_FILE_CREATE_PRIVATE in @flags the file will be made readable only to the current user, to the level that is supported on the target filesystem.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If you pass in a non-%NULL @etag value, then this value is compared to the current entity tag of the file, and if they differ an %G_IO_ERROR_WRONG_ETAG error is returned. This generally means that the file has been changed since you last read it. You can get the new etag from g_file_output_stream_get_etag() after you've finished writing and closed the #GFileOutputStream. When you load a new file you can use g_file_input_stream_query_info() to get the etag of the file.
If @make_backup is %TRUE, this function will attempt to make a backup of the current file before overwriting it. If this fails a %G_IO_ERROR_CANT_CREATE_BACKUP error will be returned. If you want to replace anyway, try again with @make_backup set to %FALSE.
If the file is a directory the %G_IO_ERROR_IS_DIRECTORY error will be returned, and if the file is some other form of non-regular file then a %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_REGULAR_FILE error will be returned. Some file systems don't allow all file names, and may return an %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_FILENAME error, and if the name is to long %G_IO_ERROR_FILENAME_TOO_LONG will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.

parameter.name: etag
parameter.parameter_description: an optional <link linkend="gfile-etag">entity tag</link> for the current #GFile, or #NULL to ignore

parameter.name: make_backup
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if a backup should be created

function.return: a #GFileOutputStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_replace_async
function.description:
Asynchronously overwrites the file, replacing the contents, possibly creating a backup copy of the file first.
For more details, see g_file_replace() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_replace_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: etag
parameter.parameter_description: an <link linkend="gfile-etag">entity tag</link> for the current #GFile, or NULL to ignore

parameter.name: make_backup
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if a backup should be created

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the <link linkend="io-priority">I/O priority</link> of the request

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_replace_contents
function.description:
Replaces the contents of @file with @contents of @length bytes.
If @etag is specified (not %NULL), any existing file must have that etag, or the error %G_IO_ERROR_WRONG_ETAG will be returned.
If @make_backup is %TRUE, this function will attempt to make a backup of @file.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
