If the interaction is cancelled by the cancellation object, or by the user then %G_TLS_INTERACTION_FAILED will be returned with an error that contains a %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED error code. Certain implementations may not support immediate cancellation.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: an optional location to place an error on failure

function.return: The status of the ask password interaction.

function.name: g_tls_interaction_ask_password_async
function.description:
Run asynchronous interaction to ask the user for a password. In general, g_tls_interaction_invoke_ask_password() should be used instead of this function.
Derived subclasses usually implement a password prompt, although they may also choose to provide a password from elsewhere. The @password value will be filled in and then @callback will be called. Alternatively the user may abort this password request, which will usually abort the TLS connection.
If the interaction is cancelled by the cancellation object, or by the user then %G_TLS_INTERACTION_FAILED will be returned with an error that contains a %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED error code. Certain implementations may not support immediate cancellation.
Certain implementations may not support immediate cancellation.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: will be called when the interaction completes

function.name: g_tls_interaction_ask_password_finish
function.description:
Complete an ask password user interaction request. This should be once the g_tls_interaction_ask_password_async() completion callback is called.
If %G_TLS_INTERACTION_HANDLED is returned, then the #GTlsPassword passed to g_tls_interaction_ask_password() will have its password filled in.
If the interaction is cancelled by the cancellation object, or by the user then %G_TLS_INTERACTION_FAILED will be returned with an error that contains a %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED error code.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: result
parameter.parameter_description: the result passed to the callback

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: an optional location to place an error on failure

function.return: The status of the ask password interaction.

function.name: g_tls_interaction_invoke_ask_password
function.description:
Invoke the interaction to ask the user for a password. It invokes this interaction in the main loop, specifically the #GMainContext returned by g_main_context_get_thread_default() when the interaction is created. This is called by called by #GTlsConnection or #GTlsDatabase to ask the user for a password.
Derived subclasses usually implement a password prompt, although they may also choose to provide a password from elsewhere. The @password value will be filled in and then @callback will be called. Alternatively the user may abort this password request, which will usually abort the TLS connection.
The implementation can either be a synchronous (eg: modal dialog) or an asynchronous one (eg: modeless dialog). This function will take care of calling which ever one correctly.
If the interaction is cancelled by the cancellation object, or by the user then %G_TLS_INTERACTION_FAILED will be returned with an error that contains a %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED error code. Certain implementations may not support immediate cancellation.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: an optional location to place an error on failure

function.return: The status of the ask password interaction.

function.name: g_tls_password_get_description
function.description:
Get a description string about what the password will be used for.
Since: 2.30
function.return: The description of the password.

function.name: g_tls_password_get_flags
function.description:
Get flags about the password.
Since: 2.30
function.return: The flags about the password.

function.name: g_tls_password_get_value
function.description:
Get the password value. If @length is not %NULL then it will be filled in with the length of the password value. (Note that the password value is not nul-terminated, so you can only pass %NULL for @length in contexts where you know the password will have a certain fixed length.)
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: location to place the length of the password.

function.return: The password value (owned by the password object).

function.name: g_tls_password_get_warning
function.description:
Get a user readable translated warning. Usually this warning is a representation of the password flags returned from g_tls_password_get_flags().
Since: 2.30
function.return: The warning.

function.name: g_tls_password_new
function.description: Create a new #GTlsPassword object.

parameter.name: description
parameter.parameter_description: description of what the password is for

function.return: The newly allocated password object

function.name: g_tls_password_set_description
function.description:
Set a description string about what the password will be used for.
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_tls_password_set_flags
function.description:
Set flags about the password.
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_tls_password_set_value
function.description:
Set the value for this password. The @value will be copied by the password object.
Specify the @length, for a non-nul-terminated password. Pass -1 as @length if using a nul-terminated password, and @length will be calculated automatically. (Note that the terminating nul is not considered part of the password in this case.)
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the password, or -1

function.name: g_tls_password_set_value_full
function.description:
Provide the value for this password.
The @value will be owned by the password object, and later freed using the @destroy function callback.
Specify the @length, for a non-nul-terminated password. Pass -1 as @length if using a nul-terminated password, and @length will be calculated automatically. (Note that the terminating nul is not considered part of the password in this case.)
Virtual: set_value Since: 2.30

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the password, or -1

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: a function to use to free the password.

function.name: g_tls_password_set_warning
function.description:
Set a user readable translated warning. Usually this warning is a representation of the password flags returned from g_tls_password_get_flags().
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_tls_server_connection_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GTlsServerConnection wrapping @base_io_stream (which must have pollable input and output streams).
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError for error reporting, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: the new #GTlsServerConnection, or %NULL on error

function.name: g_unix_connection_receive_credentials
function.description:
Receives credentials from the sending end of the connection. The sending end has to call g_unix_connection_send_credentials() (or similar) for this to work.
As well as reading the credentials this also reads (and discards) a single byte from the stream, as this is required for credentials passing to work on some implementations.
Other ways to exchange credentials with a foreign peer includes the #GUnixCredentialsMessage type and g_socket_get_credentials() function.
Since: 2.26
function.return: Received credentials on success (free with g_object_unref()), %NULL if @error is set.

function.name: g_unix_connection_receive_credentials_async
function.description:
Asynchronously receive credentials.
For more details, see g_unix_connection_receive_credentials() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_unix_connection_receive_credentials_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_unix_connection_receive_credentials_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous receive credentials operation started with g_unix_connection_receive_credentials_async().
Since: 2.32
function.return: a #GCredentials, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_unix_connection_receive_fd
function.description:
Receives a file descriptor from the sending end of the connection. The sending end has to call g_unix_connection_send_fd() for this to work.
As well as reading the fd this also reads a single byte from the stream, as this is required for fd passing to work on some implementations.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError for error reporting, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: a file descriptor on success, -1 on error.

function.name: g_unix_connection_send_credentials
function.description:
Passes the credentials of the current user the receiving side of the connection. The receiving end has to call g_unix_connection_receive_credentials() (or similar) to accept the credentials.
As well as sending the credentials this also writes a single NUL byte to the stream, as this is required for credentials passing to work on some implementations.
Other ways to exchange credentials with a foreign peer includes the #GUnixCredentialsMessage type and g_socket_get_credentials() function.
Since: 2.26
function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE if @error is set.

function.name: g_unix_connection_send_credentials_async
function.description:
Asynchronously send credentials.
For more details, see g_unix_connection_send_credentials() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_unix_connection_send_credentials_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_unix_connection_send_credentials_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous send credentials operation started with g_unix_connection_send_credentials_async().
Since: 2.32
function.return: %TRUE if the operation was successful, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: g_unix_connection_send_fd
function.description:
Passes a file descriptor to the receiving side of the connection. The receiving end has to call g_unix_connection_receive_fd() to accept the file descriptor.
As well as sending the fd this also writes a single byte to the stream, as this is required for fd passing to work on some implementations.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError for error reporting, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: a %TRUE on success, %NULL on error.

function.name: g_unix_credentials_message_get_credentials
function.description:
Gets the credentials stored in @message.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A #GCredentials instance. Do not free, it is owned by @message.

function.name: g_unix_credentials_message_is_supported
function.description:
Checks if passing #GCredentials on a #GSocket is supported on this platform.
Since: 2.26
function.return: %TRUE if supported, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_unix_credentials_message_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixCredentialsMessage with credentials matching the current processes.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a new #GUnixCredentialsMessage

function.name: g_unix_credentials_message_new_with_credentials
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixCredentialsMessage holding @credentials.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a new #GUnixCredentialsMessage

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_append
function.description:
Adds a file descriptor to @list.
The file descriptor is duplicated using dup(). You keep your copy of the descriptor and the copy contained in @list will be closed when @list is finalized.
A possible cause of failure is exceeding the per-process or system-wide file descriptor limit.
The index of the file descriptor in the list is returned. If you use this index with g_unix_fd_list_get() then you will receive back a duplicated copy of the same file descriptor.
Since: 2.24
function.return: the index of the appended fd in case of success, else -1 (and @error is set)

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_get
function.description:
Gets a file descriptor out of @list.
@index_ specifies the index of the file descriptor to get. It is a programmer error for @index_ to be out of range; see g_unix_fd_list_get_length().
The file descriptor is duplicated using dup() and set as close-on-exec before being returned. You must call close() on it when you are done.
A possible cause of failure is exceeding the per-process or system-wide file descriptor limit.
Since: 2.24
function.return: the file descriptor, or -1 in case of error

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_get_length
function.description:
Gets the length of @list (ie: the number of file descriptors contained within).
Since: 2.24
function.return: the length of @list

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixFDList containing no file descriptors.
Since: 2.24
function.return: a new #GUnixFDList

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_new_from_array
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixFDList containing the file descriptors given in @fds. The file descriptors become the property of the new list and may no longer be used by the caller. The array itself is owned by the caller.
Each file descriptor in the array should be set to close-on-exec.
If @n_fds is -1 then @fds must be terminated with -1.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: fds
parameter.parameter_description: the initial list of file descriptors

function.return: a new #GUnixFDList

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_peek_fds
function.description:
Returns the array of file descriptors that is contained in this object.
After this call, the descriptors remain the property of @list. The caller must not close them and must not free the array. The array is valid only until @list is changed in any way.
If @length is non-%NULL then it is set to the number of file descriptors in the returned array. The returned array is also terminated with -1.
This function never returns %NULL. In case there are no file descriptors contained in @list, an empty array is returned.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the length of the returned array, or %NULL

function.return: an array of file descriptors

function.name: g_unix_fd_list_steal_fds
function.description:
Returns the array of file descriptors that is contained in this object.
After this call, the descriptors are no longer contained in @list. Further calls will return an empty list (unless more descriptors have been added).
The return result of this function must be freed with g_free(). The caller is also responsible for closing all of the file descriptors. The file descriptors in the array are set to close-on-exec.
If @length is non-%NULL then it is set to the number of file descriptors in the returned array. The returned array is also terminated with -1.
This function never returns %NULL. In case there are no file descriptors contained in @list, an empty array is returned.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the length of the returned array, or %NULL

function.return: an array of file descriptors

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_append_fd
function.description:
Adds a file descriptor to @message.
The file descriptor is duplicated using dup(). You keep your copy of the descriptor and the copy contained in @message will be closed when @message is finalized.
A possible cause of failure is exceeding the per-process or system-wide file descriptor limit.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE in case of success, else %FALSE (and @error is set)

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_get_fd_list
function.description:
Gets the #GUnixFDList contained in @message. This function does not return a reference to the caller, but the returned list is valid for the lifetime of @message.
Since: 2.24
function.return: the #GUnixFDList from @message

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixFDMessage containing an empty file descriptor list.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a new #GUnixFDMessage

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_new_with_fd_list
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixFDMessage containing @list.
Since: 2.24
function.return: a new #GUnixFDMessage

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_steal_fds
function.description:
Returns the array of file descriptors that is contained in this object.
After this call, the descriptors are no longer contained in @message. Further calls will return an empty list (unless more descriptors have been added).
The return result of this function must be freed with g_free(). The caller is also responsible for closing all of the file descriptors.
If @length is non-%NULL then it is set to the number of file descriptors in the returned array. The returned array is also terminated with -1.
This function never returns %NULL. In case there are no file descriptors contained in @message, an empty array is returned.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the length of the returned array, or %NULL

function.return: an array of file descriptors

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_get_close_fd
function.description:
Returns whether the file descriptor of @stream will be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20
function.return: %TRUE if the file descriptor is closed when done

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_get_fd
function.description:
Return the UNIX file descriptor that the stream reads from.
Since: 2.20
function.return: The file descriptor of @stream

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixInputStream for the given @fd.
If @close_fd is %TRUE, the file descriptor will be closed when the stream is closed.

parameter.name: close_fd
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the file descriptor when done

function.return: a new #GUnixInputStream

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_set_close_fd
function.description:
Sets whether the file descriptor of @stream shall be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: close_fd
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the file descriptor when done

function.name: g_unix_is_mount_path_system_internal
function.description: Determines if @mount_path is considered an implementation of the OS. This is primarily used for hiding mountable and mounted volumes that only are used in the OS and has little to no relevance to the casual user.
function.return: %TRUE if @mount_path is considered an implementation detail of the OS.

function.name: g_unix_mount_at
function.description: Gets a #GUnixMountEntry for a given mount path. If @time_read is set, it will be filled with a unix timestamp for checking if the mounts have changed since with g_unix_mounts_changed_since().

parameter.name: mount_path
parameter.parameter_description: path for a possible unix mount.

function.return: a #GUnixMountEntry.

function.name: g_unix_mount_compare
function.description: Compares two unix mounts.
function.return: 1, 0 or -1 if @mount1 is greater than, equal to, or less than @mount2, respectively.

function.name: g_unix_mount_free
function.description: Frees a unix mount.

function.description:
Checks if abstract UNIX domain socket names are supported.

function.description:
Gets @address's type.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a #GUnixSocketAddressType

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_is_abstract
function.description:
Tests if @address is abstract.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: Use g_unix_socket_address_get_address_type()
function.return: %TRUE if the address is abstract, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_path
function.description:
Gets @address's path, or for abstract sockets the "name".
Guaranteed to be zero-terminated, but an abstract socket may contain embedded zeros, and thus you should use g_unix_socket_address_get_path_len() to get the true length of this string.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the path for @address

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_path_len
function.description:
Gets the length of @address's path.
For details, see g_unix_socket_address_get_path().
Since: 2.22
function.return: the length of the path

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixSocketAddress for @path.
To create abstract socket addresses, on systems that support that, use g_unix_socket_address_new_abstract().
Since: 2.22
function.return: a new #GUnixSocketAddress

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_new_abstract
function.description:
Creates a new %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED #GUnixSocketAddress for @path.
Deprecated: Use g_unix_socket_address_new_with_type().
function.return: a new #GUnixSocketAddress

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_new_with_type
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixSocketAddress of type @type with name @path.
If @type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_PATH, this is equivalent to calling g_unix_socket_address_new().
If @path_type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT, then @path_len bytes of @path will be copied to the socket's path, and only those bytes will be considered part of the name. (If @path_len is -1, then @path is assumed to be NUL-terminated.) For example, if @path was "test", then calling g_socket_address_get_native_size() on the returned socket would return 7 (2 bytes of overhead, 1 byte for the abstract-socket indicator byte, and 4 bytes for the name "test").
If @path_type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED, then @path_len bytes of @path will be copied to the socket's path, the rest of the path will be padded with 0 bytes, and the entire zero-padded buffer will be considered the name. (As above, if @path_len is -1, then @path is assumed to be NUL-terminated.) In this case, g_socket_address_get_native_size() will always return the full size of a <literal>struct sockaddr_un</literal>, although g_unix_socket_address_get_path_len() will still return just the length of @path.
%G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT is preferred over %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED for new programs. Of course, when connecting to a server created by another process, you must use the appropriate type corresponding to how that process created its listening socket.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a new #GUnixSocketAddress

function.return: %TRUE, %FALSE if operation failed.

Ejects a volume. This is an asynchronous operation, and is finished by calling g_volume_eject_with_operation_finish() with the @volume and #GAsyncResult data returned in the @callback.

function.name: g_volume_enumerate_identifiers
function.description: Gets the kinds of <link linkend="volume-identifier">identifiers</link> that @volume has. Use g_volume_get_identifier() to obtain the identifiers themselves.
function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of strings containing kinds of identifiers. Use g_strfreev() to free.

function.name: g_volume_get_activation_root
function.description:
Gets the activation root for a #GVolume if it is known ahead of mount time. Returns %NULL otherwise. If not %NULL and if @volume is mounted, then the result of g_mount_get_root() on the #GMount object obtained from g_volume_get_mount() will always either be equal or a prefix of what this function returns. In other words, in code
<programlisting> GMount *mount; GFile *mount_root GFile *volume_activation_root;
mount = g_volume_get_mount (volume); / * mounted, so never NULL * / mount_root = g_mount_get_root (mount); volume_activation_root = g_volume_get_activation_root(volume); / * assume not NULL * / </programlisting>
then the expression
<programlisting> (g_file_has_prefix (volume_activation_root, mount_root) || g_file_equal (volume_activation_root, mount_root)) </programlisting>
will always be %TRUE.
Activation roots are typically used in #GVolumeMonitor implementations to find the underlying mount to shadow, see g_mount_is_shadowed() for more details.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the activation root of @volume or %NULL. Use g_object_unref() to free.

function.name: g_volume_get_drive
function.description: Gets the drive for the @volume.
function.return: a #GDrive or %NULL if @volume is not associated with a drive. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_icon
function.description: Gets the icon for @volume.
function.return: a #GIcon. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_identifier
function.description: Gets the identifier of the given kind for @volume. See the <link linkend="volume-identifier">introduction</link> for more information about volume identifiers.

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the requested identfier, or %NULL if the #GVolume doesn't have this kind of identifier

function.description: Gets the mount for the @volume.
function.return: a #GMount or %NULL if @volume isn't mounted. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_name

function.name: g_volume_get_uuid
function.description: Gets the UUID for the @volume. The reference is typically based on the file system UUID for the volume in question and should be considered an opaque string. Returns %NULL if there is no UUID available.
function.return: the UUID for @volume or %NULL if no UUID can be computed. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_adopt_orphan_mount
function.description:
This function should be called by any #GVolumeMonitor implementation when a new #GMount object is created that is not associated with a #GVolume object. It must be called just before emitting the @mount_added signal.
If the return value is not %NULL, the caller must associate the returned #GVolume object with the #GMount. This involves returning it in its g_mount_get_volume() implementation. The caller must also listen for the "removed" signal on the returned object and give up its reference when handling that signal
Similary, if implementing g_volume_monitor_adopt_orphan_mount(), the implementor must take a reference to @mount and return it in its g_volume_get_mount() implemented. Also, the implementor must listen for the "unmounted" signal on @mount and give up its reference upon handling that signal.
There are two main use cases for this function.
One is when implementing a user space file system driver that reads blocks of a block device that is already represented by the native volume monitor (for example a CD Audio file system driver). Such a driver will generate its own #GMount object that needs to be associated with the #GVolume object that represents the volume.
The other is for implementing a #GVolumeMonitor whose sole purpose is to return #GVolume objects representing entries in the users "favorite servers" list or similar.
Deprecated: 2.20: Instead of using this function, #GVolumeMonitor implementations should instead create shadow mounts with the URI of the mount they intend to adopt. See the proxy volume monitor in gvfs for an example of this. Also see g_mount_is_shadowed(), g_mount_shadow() and g_mount_unshadow() functions.

parameter.name: mount
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMount object to find a parent for

function.return: the #GVolume object that is the parent for @mount or %NULL if no wants to adopt the #GMount.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get
function.description: Gets the volume monitor used by gio.
function.return: a reference to the #GVolumeMonitor used by gio. Call g_object_unref() when done with it.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get_connected_drives

Gets a list of drives connected to the system.
The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), after its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().
function.return: a #GList of connected #GDrive objects.

function.description: Finds a #GMount object by its UUID (see g_mount_get_uuid())

The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), after its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_volume_mount
function.description:
Mounts a volume. This is an asynchronous operation, and is finished by calling g_volume_mount_finish() with the @volume and #GAsyncResult returned in the @callback.
Virtual: mount_fn

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data that gets passed to @callback

function.name: g_volume_mount_finish
function.description:
Finishes mounting a volume. If any errors occurred during the operation, @error will be set to contain the errors and %FALSE will be returned.
If the mount operation succeeded, g_volume_get_mount() on @volume is guaranteed to return the mount right after calling this function; there's no need to listen for the 'mount-added' signal on #GVolumeMonitor.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store an error, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: %TRUE, %FALSE if operation failed.

function.name: g_volume_should_automount
function.description: Returns whether the volume should be automatically mounted.
function.return: %TRUE if the volume should be automatically mounted.

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_get_file_info

Creates a new #GZlibCompressor.
Since: 2.24

parameter.parameter_description: The format to use for the compressed data

function.return: a new #GZlibCompressor

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_set_file_info
function.description:
Sets @file_info in @compressor. If non-%NULL, and @compressor's #GZlibCompressor:format property is %G_ZLIB_COMPRESSOR_FORMAT_GZIP, it will be used to set the file name and modification time in the GZIP header of the compressed data.
Note: it is an error to call this function while a compression is in progress; it may only be called immediately after creation of @compressor, or after resetting it with g_converter_reset().
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_zlib_decompressor_get_file_info
function.description:
Retrieves the #GFileInfo constructed from the GZIP header data of compressed data processed by @compressor, or %NULL if @decompressor's #GZlibDecompressor:format property is not %G_ZLIB_COMPRESSOR_FORMAT_GZIP, or the header data was not fully processed yet, or it not present in the data stream at all.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a #GFileInfo, or %NULL

function.description:
Creates a new #GZlibDecompressor.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: The format to use for the compressed data

function.return: a new #GZlibDecompressor

function.name: get_all_desktop_entries_for_mime_type
function.description:
Returns all the desktop ids for @mime_type. The desktop files are listed in an order so that default applications are listed before non-default ones, and handlers for inherited mimetypes are listed after the base ones.
Optionally doesn't list the desktop ids given in the @except
function.return: a #GList containing the desktop ids which claim to handle @mime_type.

function.name: gvdb_table_get_raw_value
function.description:
Looks up a value named @key in @file.
This call is equivalent to gvdb_table_get_value() except that it never byteswaps the value.
function.return: a #GVariant, or %NULL

function.name: gvdb_table_get_table
function.description:
Looks up the hash table named @key in @file.
The toplevel hash table in a #GvdbTable can contain reference to child hash tables (and those can contain further references...).
If @key is not found in @file then %NULL is returned. Otherwise, a new #GvdbTable is returned, referring to the child hashtable as contained in the file. This newly-created #GvdbTable does not depend on the continued existence of @file.
You should call gvdb_table_unref() on the return result when you no longer require it.
function.return: a new #GvdbTable, or %NULL

function.name: gvdb_table_get_value
function.description:
Looks up a value named @key in @file.
If the value is not found then %NULL is returned. Otherwise, a new #GVariant instance is returned. The #GVariant does not depend on the continued existence of @file.
You should call g_variant_unref() on the return result when you no longer require it.
function.return: a #GVariant, or %NULL

function.name: gvdb_table_has_value
function.description:
Checks for a value named @key in @file.
Note: this function does not consider non-value nodes (other hash tables, for example).
function.return: %TRUE if @key is in the table

function.name: gvdb_table_is_valid
function.description:
Checks if the table is still valid.
An on-disk GVDB can be marked as invalid. This happens when the file has been replaced. The appropriate action is typically to reopen the file.
function.return: %TRUE if @table is still valid

function.name: gvdb_table_list
function.description:
List all of the keys that appear below @key. The nesting of keys within the hash file is defined by the program that created the hash file. One thing is constant: each item in the returned array can be concatenated to @key to obtain the full name of that key.
It is not possible to tell from this function if a given key is itself a path, a value, or another hash table; you are expected to know this for yourself.
You should call g_strfreev() on the return result when you no longer require it.
function.return: a %NULL-terminated string array

function.name: gvdb_table_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GvdbTable from the contents of the file found at @filename.
The only time this function fails is if the file cannot be opened. In that case, the #GError that is returned will be an error from g_mapped_file_new().
An empty or otherwise corrupted file is considered to be a valid #GvdbTable with no entries.
You should call gvdb_table_unref() on the return result when you no longer require it.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the path to the hash file

parameter.name: trusted
parameter.parameter_description: if the contents of @filename are trusted

function.return: a new #GvdbTable

function.name: gvdb_table_new_from_data
function.description:
Creates a new #GvdbTable from the data in @data.
An empty or otherwise corrupted data is considered to be a valid #GvdbTable with no entries.
You should call gvdb_table_unref() on the return result when you no longer require it.

parameter.name: trusted
parameter.parameter_description: if the contents of @data are trusted

function.return: a new #GvdbTable

function.name: gvdb_table_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count on @file.
function.return: a new reference on @file

function.name: gvdb_table_unref
function.description:
Decreases the reference count on @file, possibly freeing it.
Since: 2.26

function.name: gvdb_table_walk
function.description:
Looks up the list at @key and iterate over the items in it.
First, @open_func is called to signal that we are starting to iterate over the list. Then the list is iterated. When all items in the list have been iterated over, the @close_func is called.
When iterating, if a given item in the list is a value then @value_func is called.
If a given item in the list is itself a list then @open_func is called. If that function returns %TRUE then the walk begins iterating the items in the sublist, until there are no more items, at which point a matching @close_func call is made. If @open_func returns %FALSE then no iteration of the sublist occurs and no corresponding @close_func call is made.

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: a key corresponding to a list

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data to pass to the callbacks

function.name: handle_created
function.description: A callback function for the directory diff calculation routine, produces G_FILE_MONITOR_EVENT_CREATED event for a created file.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: file name of a new file.

parameter.name: inode
parameter.parameter_description: inode number of a new file.

function.name: handle_deleted
function.description: A callback function for the directory diff calculation routine, produces G_FILE_MONITOR_EVENT_DELETED event for a deleted file.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: file name of the removed file.

parameter.name: inode
parameter.parameter_description: inode number of the removed file.

function.name: handle_moved
function.description: A callback function for the directory diff calculation routine, produces G_FILE_MONITOR_EVENT_MOVED event on a move.

parameter.name: from_path
parameter.parameter_description: file name of the source file.

parameter.name: from_inode
parameter.parameter_description: inode number of the source file.

parameter.name: to_path
parameter.parameter_description: file name of the replaced file.

parameter.name: to_inode
parameter.parameter_description: inode number of the replaced file.

function.name: handle_overwritten
function.description: A callback function for the directory diff calculation routine, produces G_FILE_MONITOR_EVENT_DELETED/CREATED event pair when an overwrite occurs in the directory (see dep-list for details).

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: file name of the overwritten file.

parameter.name: node
parameter.parameter_description: inode number of the overwritten file.

function.name: kevents_extend_sz
function.description: Extends the allocated memory, if needed.

parameter.name: n_new
parameter.parameter_description: the number of new objects to be added

function.name: kevents_free
function.description: Resets the kevents object and frees all the associated memory.

function.name: kevents_init_sz
function.description: Initializes a #kevents object.

parameter.name: n_initial
parameter.parameter_description: the initial preallocated memory size. If it is less than %KEVENTS_EXTEND_COUNT, this value will be used instead.

function.name: kevents_reduce
function.description:
Reduces the allocated heap size, if needed.
If the allocated heap size is >= 3*used and 2*used >= %KEVENTS_EXTEND_COUNT, reduce it to 2*used.

function.name: km_scan_missing
function.description:
The core missing files watching routine.
Traverses through a list of missing files, tries to start watching each with kqueue, removes the appropriate entry and invokes a user callback if the file has appeared.
function.return: %FALSE if no missing files left, %TRUE otherwise.

function.name: kqueue_notification
function.description: Represents a pool of (struct kevent) objects.

parameter.name: memory
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the allocated memory

function.name: kqueue_sub
function.description: Represents a subscription on a file or directory.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a name of the file to monitor

parameter.name: fd
parameter.parameter_description: the associated file descriptor (used by kqueue)

function.name: mime_info_cache_reload
function.description: Reload the mime information for the @dir.

function.name: process_kqueue_notifications
function.description:
Processes notifications, coming from the kqueue thread.
Reads notifications from the command file descriptor, emits the "changed" event on the appropriate monitor.
A typical GIO Channel callback function.
function.return: %TRUE
